official-title.#text: To amend title 5, United States Code, to ensure proper manpower on the United States border and to provide for reforms to rates of pay for Border Patrol agents.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Border Patrol Pay Reform Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The purposes of this section are—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and to ensure that Border Patrol agents are sufficiently ready to conduct necessary work and will perform overtime hours in excess of a 40-hour workweek based on the needs of the employing agency; and

text.#text: the term
detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling of aliens, commercial goods, narcotics, weapons, or contraband into the United States;
arresting individuals suspected of conduct described in subparagraph (A);

being on approved annual, sick, or administrative leave;

being on excused absence with pay for relocation purposes;

caring for the canine assigned to the Border Patrol agent, which may not exceed 1 hour per day; or
engaging in an activity similar to an activity described in any of the preceding subparagraphs while temporarily away from the regular duty assignment of the Border Patrol agent;

Not later than 30 days before the first day of each year beginning after the date of enactment of this section, a Border Patrol agent shall make an election as to whether such agent shall, for such year—

and how to make such an election.

should take such action as is necessary to ensure that not more than 10 percent of the Border Patrol agents stationed at a location decline to be assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of pay or the level 2 border patrol rate of pay.
